review: My wife immediately migrated to the more user-friendly user interface of Fire TV over our old stand-by media streamer, a PS3.  I like not only the layout of menus and speedy ease of navigation, but also am impressed with the apparent ability of the stick to stream higher quality video over my wireless network. To do it justice, I now need to upgrade my older Netgear router to take full advantage of the Fire Stick's capabilities. What's a tech nerd to do? Such a first world problem.Set up was simple. It may be overkill, but I use MAC filtering on my network and found the Fire Stick's MAC address under Settings > System > About. Such a configuration is by no means necessary, so don't worry if that "MAC filtering" is Greek to you. Though the stick itself plugs into a USB port on your TV, be advised that the Fire Stick will not work properly using power from a USB port. You WILL need to give this device AC power from an outlet with the hardware provided. But really, what's another wire in my rat's nest anyway?Now I'm tempted to get the super-duper voice remote to go with...

review: I am a prime member, so I get  my money's worth and more. This device is great, much faster than my older ROKU. A fine way to "cut the cable". (Don't forget to keep your internet, though.)Update: Had a problem with the Fire keeping up with a movie rented from Amazon, it kept stopping to spool up. I had said nothing to amazon yet, but they keep a virtual eye on these things, apparently.I received an email from them stating that they noticed the glitch, and REFUNDED MY $$ for the rental! They did make a point that Refunding of Rented Video is not something they normally do, and i think it is not likely to happen again anytime soon, but still, great service.They went on to tell me how to clean off the 'Stick's apps and info, to get it rebooted, so to speak. I haven't done it yet, but will today. (LINK PROVIDED BELOW)I have never had service like this from any other streaming service. I did have the problem, but Amazon cared that I had it, and they made it right.Although I have a full (FIOS 50/50) Wireless signal within 24 inches of the FireStick, and nothing else taking bandwidth (so it was not my equipment or my signal) I know that setup of equipment sometimes loads up memory with junk. Cleaning it up just might do the trick.Here's a copy of the "troubleshooting" link for ways you can "potentially improve your viewing experience":You can copy and paste it in a browser.http://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=201431300
